A Review of the Work of the   Charleston regional planning Committee,  an Estimate of its Future,  and a Request to the Carnegie Corporation  for a Grant to continue its work to 1943.  This review is not a compete report. The report will follow after January 1, 1942.  In the spring of 1940 a group of people who were concerned about the deeterious effect of haphazard explansion and i-considered restorations organized themseves into a committee to study the need for practical preservation and planned  growth of Charleston. McCormack secretory of tho Committee  Two grants have been made to the Carolina Art  Association for the work of the Committee: [1] on December 27, 1939, $600 for the services of Mr. Frederick aw Olmstead, and [2] on May 13, 1940, $2,500. for the services of secretaria and research assistance for one year. The atter grant terminated on May 13, 1941, but Miss Helen G. McCormack, former director of the Vaentine Museum of Richmond, Virginia, was engaged for the year 1941.  Suggestions for procedure grew out of the consutations with and report of Mr. Olmstead. Two needs were obvious:  [1] an inventory of the whole city  to determine the buiding

As  a first step toward the achievement of these ends tha committee asked for and obtained a grant from the Carnegie Corporation to make the inventory and to take measures to estabish itself as the central agency.  On January 1, 1941, the Charleston regional planning Committee began the architectural survey which is the basis of its studies, the findings are recorded upon cards, which carry photographs of buildings and facts concerning use, condition, period, source of interest, value, history and bibiography. The cards are reviewed by three architects and an historian on the Committee. In addition to the buildings cards, 45 parks, cemeteries, groups and vistas have been recorded. This last cassification will be greaty explanded. Since the rating Is not compete it is impossibe to give the final score, but the proportions so far are 1 Nationally important buiding to 4 valuable to the city, to 8 vauable, to 9 notable, to I2 mentionable. When the buildings are rated they are located by coor symbos upon a map. In addition to the cord cataogue of architecture a small ibrary on planning is being assembed, and facts reating to the city"s cultural and welfare obigations, and its economic background. In short, the Committee is trying to measure the cty"s capacity to preserve its inheritance and its need of a more suitable pattern for wholesome contemporarary life. The Defense effort here, as esewhere, shows up the weak spots in our hitherto unplanned growth. should not the present effor to improve living conditions to meet the immediate emergency be combined with a definite program for the future?   No just estimate of the Committee"s work can be made at the end of a first year of study end activity. When the Inventory is competed, the Committee is planning to announce its findings in the form of an exhibition. The exhibition is scheduled at the Art Associaltion"s Gibbes Art Gallery late in December, and to continue into the first months of 1942. The exhibition will show by means of facts and photographs the number and importance of the buildings worthy of protection, and those threatened with loss by diapidation and demoition, end will show the need for a program of preservation. Moreover, it will recognize the achievements already made in the cause of preservation, from the Federal government"s participation in saving two rice mis as Coast Guard and Nava Patro Stations to the accompishments of individuals who hove carefully restored shops and singe houses.
